What did early Canadian pioneer eat?
A QUESTIONNAIRE

(Instructions: Fill in as much of this questionnaire as you can and mail it to Saskatchewan Archives Office, Box 100, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, Sask.)

Name: Mrs. Howard Burdett
Address: Killarney, Sask.
Birthplace: Perry Sound, Ont.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS
   Came to Canada: 1906
   What year did you start housekeeping in Eastern Canada? 1887
   Where did you set up housekeeping? In a house with Mr. and Mrs. Smith
   Where had you been living before that? At Killarney, Ont.
   For how many people did you prepare meals? Four people at first.
   How far was it to your nearest store? 20 miles
   How often could a visit be made to the store? Monthly
   What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Flour, jam, oatmeal, corn syrup, brown sugar, tea, corn meal, (quick) limes, cheese, a can of tomatoes, etc.

2. FLOUR AND OTHER GRAIN PRODUCTS
   What brand of white flour did you use in the early years? Harvest Queen
   Second grade flour: Rolled wheat
   In what quantities did you buy it? One sack at a time, all that could be afforded
   What was the usual price per hundred pounds of white flour? About $2.00 per bag
   How much did you use Graham flour?
   Whole wheat flour?
   Was flour milled locally? Yes
   How far away? What year? 1944-1946
   What was the price for a twenty pound bag of rolled oats? About 8 cents
   What other grain products did you use?
   Cornmeal? Yes
   Whole wheat?
   Farina?
   Other?
   Did you grind your own wheat for porridge? No
   How did you grind it?

Mention any changes in the use of fuels which have taken place since you first started housekeeping, giving dates where possible. In later years before depression we used coal, in 1934 in drought years we moved to northern Saskatchewan. Since then we have had abundance of good wood which I prefer to coal.

18. WRAPPINGS AND CONTAINERS

Mention any changes which you recall in the wrappings and containers received with the food you purchased (give dates where possible).

In the early years from 1879-1900, groceries were sold in paper bags, jam in wooden jars tied in linen, tea was sold in cans, as large as 50 lbs. This is down to 1 lb. The worst was no cellulose packages those days, and was wrapped, there was no easy opening, flour in white sacks, fruit melons, seeds were purchased all in bulk, much less canned goods. There was no salted salt as far as I know. Candy was in bulk, you could buy a typical day's meal (breakfast, dinner & supper) for the earliest year you can remember. 18. **Local Produce**

20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

In early days the housewife had to prepare everything for the meals. There was no prepared foods ready to place on the table, such as canned meats, cakes &c., as today. And a good cook was considered OK if she could make an appetizing, appetizing meal out of very little.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homestead and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

In the early homestead days we kept cows & churned a quantity of butter, also sold eggs to the store. There was no grading in those days. Mother & I often would rise early & drive our horse & buggy 20 miles to town with our load of butter & eggs, & take it to the store for groceries whatever was needed. We would have such a load we could hardly put in the buggy. Flour, oatmeal, sugar, tea, were, twice over, all we was needed on the farm. It was a long hard day in the boiling sun of summer. Afterward we had a grocery van call for a year or two. The van took our eggs & gave us groceries in return, at reasonable prices on those days.
In the early times I had before me before each channel a quantity of butter, also all eggs to the size that were no gardening without days. Myself and often would have only a little or none at all to the store. Will not break up little by egg, but to the store for growing whatever was needed. We would have such a load we could hardly get into the house floor, national, sugar, tea, coffee, flour, turnips, etc.

Our own needs on the farm, I mean a long hard day in the boiling season of summer afterward we had grown them all for a year or two. We then took our apple and gave us a generous harvest, oil measure all prices for three days.
